comment_text: take this course. easily my favourite cos course I've taken. be proactive with the project

Make sure to attend lectures,  as the concepts they cover are invaluable in completing the assignments. That being said, if you are not able to make some of the lectures, it is alright; just make sure to browse the course website for related files on the concepts covered in class.

you might hear from some people that the project is crazy and you'll have to pull all-nighters if you want to do a cool project. i want to dispel that myth. i loved this course so much, and our team made something that will hopefully be a tigerapp. the process was really fun and i'm so proud of what we were able to do. and the latest we ever stayed up was 2am (even then you could argue we didn't need to). we mostly used the tech stack that is taught in class (you really don't need to use React if your app is not like super complicated or doesn't use a lot of duplicated components). it was also nice because the assignments ended up making the app-building process a lot smoother (having a good partner also makes the assignments a lot better). my best advice is to find a team of people you get along well with and who are willing to put in the work. if i could do anything differently, i would have been more organized and designated tasks better early on instead of just doing a lot of it myself (your teammates can't help if you never talk about how). prof. dondero is great and clearly cares a lot about the course. the lectures are really thorough, and there is so much valuable SWE knowledge packed into them. the only downside is that they can be a bit dry and i honestly wasn't super engaged. but again, prof. dondero is a great teacher. he is super responsive on Ed, and you should go to his office hours if you get the chance (he is super helpful with project stuff).

Take it! It's a lot of work but you learn a lot, and Professor Dondero is so sweet and helpful (he would respond in very detailed Ed posts and very promptly too). Try to pick good teammates though (mine really slacked off towards the end so it was super stressful), and we're graded as a team so that was a bit unfortunate.

Consider this class like 1.5 classes - the assignments and the project both require considerable attention, but everything is certainly very doable with a reasonable assignment partner and project group. Don't try to do everything alone - this class is all about working well in teams!

GREAT CLASS! Honestly one of my favorite COS classes at Princeton -- Dondero's amazing, the experience of actually building an entire app from start to finish front to back is really rewarding, and the class gives you a lot of transferable skills for the real world. However, it can really be a time suck. I was tweaking like every other week because of the tight deadlines and milestones, and its hard to fit like tens of hours of debugging (or more!) into your schedule. still a great class and i don't regret taking it. just maybe don't do it in a five-course semester or with another high workload class
Only take if you really want to get into web development and frontend/ backend coding. Very good class if interested in that though.

Take this if you want to learn a ton about real-life app design! Instructor is a good-hearted man who wants the best for his students. While the subject matter is not exactly riveting, his passion dragged us through the subject matter and I learned a lot

Take it! This is the only class at Princeton (at least from all the courses I have taken) that will give you a day-to-day software engineering experience. Make sure to come to the class with the group of people that you plan to work with because this class can become a nightmare if your group mates aren't good (this matters for the assignment group and the project group). I also recommend challenging yourself in your project and using technologies that are not taught in the class so that you can learn stuff that the industry is using currently.

THIS IS A GREAT CLASS!! MY FAVORITE COS CLASS I HAVE TAKEN AT PRINCETON!!! This class truly helps you learn and build the foundation you need for jobs and software engineering internships. Everything that you do in this class feels relevant to the real world and is motivated. Professor Dondero is also amazing. You can tell that he TRULY cares about his students and wants them to succeed. I have emailed/posted on Ed before asking questions when I need help and Professor Dondero is so quick to respond. He never makes it feel like you are bothering him by asking questions. He is so generous with his students and it truly makes a difference. You feel supported as a student every step of the way and it makes the learning experience that much better.  My only advice would be to truly give this course your all. It's hard and takes a lot of work (especially with the semester long Project), but you will learn so much and it will feel so rewarding to be a better Software Engineer by the end of the course.
I think students should know what type of project they want to work on before coming in.

Lived up to the hype in my opinion. I learnt a lot about full-stack web development - and in particular React.js and Flask. I'd advise coming into the class with a group in mind so that you don't have to start project finding. Also watch out for the documentation you'll need to write at the end of the semester, particularly around dean's date -- it can easily get out of hand
Find a good group of friends who you are great at pestering to do work.
Take it! Very practical, put some effort into the project and you'll get a lot out of it. I went in barely knowing frontend/backend, but came out feeling like I could make my own projects.

This course is definitely a lot of work but definitely worth it. You learn a lot of useful skills and get to apply them for your semester long project. Be prepared to devote a lot of time for this class though as you need to work on your project weekly along with biweekly programming assignments. Very worth it though!

One of the most applied courses in the COS department, and you definitely get a lot out of it! But you also have to put so, so much in it if you want to properly learn the content / get a good grade, so be ready for that going in. Professor Dondero is such a nice professor though and will always be there to support you, truly one of my favorite professors.
I would recommend against taking this course if you already have prior experience with app development.
Take this class if you want to learn about functional coding and practical development. It is very real-world based.

If you're a COS major, take this course! It is so fun to make your own project and a great introduction to software engineering. Ideally, go in with a group, but I was able to find a group after enrolling and it worked out well. Keep in mind that it is a lot of work, but I think it's worth it.

Take this course! Prof Dondero is the GOAT.  You'll learn a ton and it'll be a blast. I strongly recommend having a group in mind before coming into the class. The latter half of this class is super time consuming, so be prepared to spend a lot of time away from other classes.

Take the class with group of people you would like to work with, will make project group creation easier and overall the experience great. It was so much fun, I could take it again if  I had all the time in the world.
Take to get a project on that SWE Resume.

Really great course! If you have the opportunity to take it I really recommend it. It has 4 smaller programming assignments and a semester-long project. The longer project might seem overwhelming but the structure of the course helps to plan it out and make sure you're on track. Also, don't think that you have to have the next big idea to take this course, they have project proposals if you don't want to think of your own.

To students thinking about 333 - take it only if you know who you're going to do the project with. Note that lectures are pretty dull if you're someone who knows web dev already (like most), and they're pretty slow.
Take it!

it's a really good course, prof dondero and the staff care so much about the students and how the course is going. lectures are very informative and helpful. probably the most useful and practical course ive taken here, definitely take it and you can walk away with actual development experience. its def a big time commitment tho, with working on the assignments, attending lecture, and working on the project all throughout, so be prepared for that but the time you put in is worth it. note for projects: be realistic with what you wanna make, have a good reliable group,  don't leave off everything for the end
go to the lectures and start on the project as soon as possible
Take this class with a group of people you would really enjoy working with since the semester-long project will be a grind.
take it! one of the most rewarding and engaging COS classes at Princeton

I came into this class with some background in frontend development, so I don't think I learned that much in this class. However, still a decent course and worth taking for the semester-long project! Lots to say, though. First, like most people mention, lectures are mind-numbingly boring, but still mandatory because of attendance with basically iClicker questions but through a website. Mainly it's teaching syntax/tools/frameworks for full stack, a lot of which are outdated now; these lectures could probably be made into YouTube videos and we would watch them on 2x speed / skip around for useful info... Dondero has good volume and speaks quickly though, and the lectures are very organized. But another thing I disliked about lectures was that he taught many MANY versions of code that taught bottom-up, and it becomes a lot to parse through to find the relevant code to help with assignments; it's only ever really the newest versions that are useful. There's only 4 assignments throughout the semester and they are very manageable. They are also partnered, but probably doable independently. Would recommend finding a group of 4 for the semester-long project and then splitting into pairs for the assignments. They say they'll "expect more" from groups of 5. Try to find a group before class starts / in the first week. Now for the project... I had learned React over the summer. Dondero really hates React for some reason, and discourages people from learning it because of the learning curve; there is kind of a learning curve, if you have 1-2 people in your group with some experience that's best. But you are allowed to use ChatGPT/Claude for the project, and they're good at React! Also I would say there is not as much support/resources as I would have liked for the project, probably because every project is going to be so different. You have weekly TA meetings, but most of them don't really have much experience in React so they're mainly there to check-in on deliverables. Similarly, it was kind of hard to figure out how to set up the project in terms of code structure; we used Vite + React (also not much support in class for Vite) in frontend and Flask in backend (taught in class). Managing the two server thing was a bit tricky, had to use Vite proxy, and then we deployed as a single server. Also would recommend having everyone use their own branch and use GitHub pull requests to avoid merge conflicts (was not taught in class)! CAS integration was not too bad, but had some help though from someone who had experience. I think more people ended up using jQuery, but in my opinion they should just be teaching React more (it's covered but not a lot) because it's definitely more useful and popular now, also more scalable. Like with React and a lot of project-related issues, Dondero will try to help as much as he can but he might not end up being helpful... As long as you have a good group though, and ask Chat a lot, you'll be fine. Definitely follow the deliverable due dates, if not stay a bit ahead of them. Each project has a self-designated "team leader" (which I was), and something that was helpful is to figure out all the tasks for the week and divvy them up. Finally, there is definitely a lot of documentation work during reading period so would really recommend you finish up your code/product work like 2-3 days before the final product is due. Overall, the project is definitely something worthy of putting on your resume, and I'm super grateful for the class to be able to support that kind of project, you don't get a lot of time to work on fun things like that elsewhere!
First COS class that I truly felt like prepared me for the job market. A LOT OF WORK and very big time commitment but absolutely worth it for every COS major
get a good group and you'll have a ton of fun

Overall a good course and taught me all the skills I wanted to learn. It's just so much information packed into one course though, I think I would have absorbed it so much better if this was split into two separate courses. Get a good group, I probably would've really struggled with this course if I didn't have an amazing project group.

great class! Dondero genuinely cares about his students, and the class teaches real SWE material. I appreciate the project and all the timelines and milestones that are embedded into the curriculum ? makes it harder to procrastinate and easier to leave the class with an amazing end product!
Good class, would recommend

Professor Dondero will do you no favors and he is a dry lecturer. Topics go by fast, but assignments are relatively fine. Good introduction to different technologies, but I wish we spent more time exploring some of them instead. Project is hit or miss. Wouldn't take it again.
One of the best COS departmental you can take.

This class is fine but kind of a slog. I would not recommend taking it unless you know what you want to do, have a solid team who agrees on how to distribute the work, and don't have too many classes with major final projects. I am sure I have learned things, but maybe not as much as I really should have in a class like this.

Sometimes lectures felt dry (following along lines of code while Prof. Dondero talks about it), but I wish I put in more effort. Prof. Dondero is amazing and you stand to gain a lot by applying yourself.
a good course especially if you want to learn about web dev
